head.title: An American Town Meeting: The Issue Is Race; The Sergeants

abstract.p: Black Army veteran Demaree Barnes letter, responding to June 7 article Which Man's Army?, in series How Race Is Lived in America, recalls friendship he formed with white soldier when both were isolated from their respective cultures

Re ''Which Man's Army'' (''How Race Is Lived in America,'' front page, June 7):
I am an Army veteran who spent three years at Fort Knox, Ky., from 1953 to 1956. I am black (born and raised in Chicago), and to put it mildly, my experience at Fort Knox was a shock.

I had all the usual experiences one would expect at that time in the South, but I think the one experience that says a great deal about race relations in America has stayed with me: on the day of my induction, I met a man whose personal profile was as different from mine as night from day. He was white, from a rural community in Illinois, a farmer all of his life with no black acquaintances.

From the moment we met at the induction center, we became inseparable! In Louisville, I was humiliated several times -- thrown out of the ''white'' waiting rooms, not allowed to go to first-run movie theaters, and so on. No one was more outraged than my friend.

So, one of my best friends in life was white: at a time when we were both isolated from our respective cultures, we found one another and believed enough in one another to have a memorable, trusting experience together.
